subject: JUnit 4

messageBody:
JUnit 4 has been available for some time on the Version4 branch of the
SourceForge CVS repository. We didn't announce its availability widely until
we thought we had something useful. We have gotten early feedback from a
handful of developers, but we now have a release that we think can be used
to write production tests.

I understand that some people have been quoting our private to-do list out
of context. Private communication between Erich and me will in future take
place more privately. It is too bad that it is not safe to let you all into
our process. It is disturbing to find one's to-do-list quoted as promises
broken or ideas stolen. It was just an old to-do list. Maybe it's time to
invest in an electron shredder :-)

The theme of JUnit 4 is to encourage more developers to write more tests by
further simplifying JUnit. To this end, we have followed NUnit's lead in
identifying tests by annotation instead of subclassing and naming
conventions. Tests can now live in any class. Tell JUnit they are there with
the @Test annotation:
@Test public void basicTransaction() {...

The assertion methods are in an Assert class which is most easily used
through static import:
import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
...
@Test public void example() {...assertEquals(2, 2);...}

Set up and tear down are handled with the @Before and @After annotations.
You can have as many @Befores and @Afters as you need. Inherited @Befores
are executed before @Befores in subclasses and inherited @Afters are
executed after @Afters in subclasses.

Shared setup is handled by @BeforeClass and @AfterClass. Methods with these
annotations are executed once before (respectively after) all the tests in
the class run.

@Ignore causes a test not to be run, but it is reported as ignored.

@Test takes two optional parameters. A test annotated @Test(timeout=100)
will fail if the test takes longer than 100 milliseconds to complete. A test
annotated @Test(expected=NullPointerException.class) will fail if a
NullPointerException is not thrown and succeed if a NullPointerException is
thrown.

Preserving existing investment in tests has taken nearly half of our
development effort. JUnit 4 is forward and backward compatible. You can run
older tests with the JUnit 4 test runner by passing them to the runner. You
can run JUnit 4 tests with older test runners by wrapping the JUnit 4 test
class in a compatibility class. The following method in a JUnit 4 test class
causes it to run correctly with the Eclipse test runner.
public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
return new JUnit4TestAdapter(AssertionTest.class);
}

JUnit 4's command line interface can be invoked with:
java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore Test1 Test2

The same interface can be invoked programmatically with:
JUnitCore.run(Test1.class, Test2.class);

If you want to know more about the details of JUnit 4, you can browse the
tests in org.junit.tests.*.

Erich and I will be participating on the JUnit lists to discuss further
simplification of JUnit 4, integration with test runners, and experiences
using it. Our experience with it (most of the tests were written JUnit 4
style) has been very positive. The complexity of JUnit 3.x is like a tiny
pebble in a shoe. It doesn't seem like much until it is gone.

Good testing,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
